caption: Last Friday, HTX celebrated its 5th anniversary with not one, but two events! In the morning, Xponents participated in a symbolic dash to HQ from eight satellite offices, mirroring how HTX was first formed in 2019 by bringing together talents from the various Home Team Departments and the Ministry of Home Affairs ( ).Later, over 1,500 Xponents gathered at Marina Bay Sands for a fun-filled dinner and dance themed Hands Across HTX.The event highlighted our journey in enhancing Singapores safety and security, as well as showcased the many innovations we have developed to exponentially empower the Home Team over the last five years.Wed like to extend a big THANK YOU to all Xponents, partners and stakeholderswe wouldnt have reached this milestone without your support.Heres to another five fruitful and eventful years ahead! caption: GLUE, GOAT, NGL, ROUGE, and SMHcan you tell which of these acronyms are evaluation metrics for Large Language Models (LLMs) and which are Gen Z slang? From training HTXs LLMs to understanding global practices on AI governance, our recent Responsible AI Day, organised by HTxAI Enterprise Group, highlighted the importance of integrating privacy, security, and governance to establish and operationalise robust responsible AI policies and practices.We were joined by Resaro, an independent third-party AI test lab, who shared global practices on AI Governance across jurisdictions and law enforcement agencies. Their presentation also touched on how AI systems can be tested to enhance performance and build user confidence.The event drew an engaged audience of about 200 participants attending both in-person and virtually. It concluded with a lively Q&A session.Find out more about what we do at HTX in the fields of data science and AI: HTXsg HTxAI LargeLanguageModel LLM ArtificialIntelligence AIp/s GLUE and ROUGE are evaluation metrics for LLMs.

caption: What a ride! After a series of intense pitching and presentations, the winner of HacX2024 was finally crowned.What is HacX? It is a hackathon jointly organised by HTX and , where young innovators are tasked with solving various challenge statementschallenges faced by Home Team Departments and HTXs Centres of Expertise. These range from safeguarding lives and properties to deterring and solving crimes, and enhancing safety for our frontline.The top 10 teams at the finals gave it their all for a shot at the grand prize of S$10,000. In the end, DataDream Team, Team REAct and Team Group 12 emerged as the top 3 winners, with DataDream Team clinching the grand prize.But it werent just the winners who impressed us with their solutionswe are proud of all the finalists who made it this far.From the semi-finals till now, we have witnessed the passion and unmistakable drive from all the teams to keep improving upon their solutions to keep Singapore safe and secure.Congratulations to the winners and everyone who participated!HTXsg Microsoft HacX Hackathon Innovation

caption: With deadlines to meet, it can be tough to find time to show care for others. But do you know that each small display of empathy can work wonders in building connections and delivering great work?According to our Values Ambassador, Jacqueline Chan, we could all use a bit of empathy. caption: Bonjour! I am here at the biennial Milipol Paris 2023 to support our Singapore Pavilion! This is the first time HTX and its partners are exhibiting the latest technological innovations at this leading event, dedicated to homeland security. I had the honour of meeting Minister Shanmugam who flew in for this exposition. I also spoke with the capable team of engineers from HTX, NCS and ST Engineering, and was exponentially mind-blown by our solutions in Securing Borders, Saving Lives, Safeguarding Public Spaces, and the one closest to my heart Solving Crimes. My apartment in Paris was broken into and turned upside down on a bright and beautiful day in Spring last year. On that fateful day, everything changed for me. The trauma was twofold. First was the burglary itself, and second, the lack of a system robust enough to render the support you need when faced with threats and dangers. Burglary, like pickpocketing, are common transgressions and you just have to learn to live with the bad and the good that comes with living in a big city. Not having closure is the only closure I got. I realized how much we have taken safety and security for granted in Singapore. None of my friends have security alarm systems installed in their homes. I would also choose to believe that you wouldnt be able to get away scot-free if you commit any crimes in Singapore, no matter how petty your misdeeds are. You will be caught, in a very short time, or eventually. It is reassuring to know that so much effort goes into advancing science and technology for homeland security to keep Singapore safe. This to me, is the freedom the world needs. Freedom to be safe. MilipolParis

cleaned_caption: Bonjour! I am here at the biennial Milipol Paris 2023 to support our Singapore Pavilion! This is the first time HTX and its partners are exhibiting the latest technological innovations at this leading event, dedicated to homeland security. I had the honour of meeting the Minister for Home Affairs who flew in for this exposition. I also spoke with the capable team of engineers from HTX, NCS and ST Engineering, and was exponentially mind-blown by our solutions in Securing Borders, Saving Lives, Safeguarding Public Spaces, and the one closest to my heart Solving Crimes. My apartment in Paris was broken into and turned upside down on a bright and beautiful day in Spring last year. On that fateful day, everything changed for me. The trauma was twofold. First was the burglary itself, and second, the lack of a system robust enough to render the support you need when faced with threats and dangers. Burglary, like pickpocketing, are common transgressions and you just have to learn to live with the bad and the good that comes with living in a big city. Not having closure is the only closure I got. I realized how much we have taken safety and security for granted in Singapore. None of my friends have security alarm systems installed in their homes. I would also choose to believe that you wouldn't be able to get away scot-free if you commit any crimes in Singapore, no matter how petty your misdeeds are. You will be caught, in a very short time, or eventually. It is reassuring to know that so much effort goes into advancing science and technology for homeland security to keep Singapore safe. This to me, is the freedom the world needs. Freedom to be safe. #MilipolParis

This is the first time HTX and its partners are exhibiting the latest technological innovations at this leading event, dedicated to homeland security. I had the honour of meeting Minister Shanmugam who flew in for this exposition. I also spoke with the capable team of engineers from HTX, NCS and ST Engineering, and was exponentially mind-blown by our solutions in Securing Borders, Saving Lives, Safeguarding Public Spaces, and the one closest to my heart Solving Crimes. My apartment in Paris was broken into and turned upside down on a bright and beautiful day in Spring last year. On that fateful day, everything changed for me. The trauma was twofold. First was the burglary itself, and second, the lack of a system robust enough to render the support you need when faced with threats and dangers. Burglary, like pickpocketing, are common transgressions and you just have to learn to live with the bad and the good that comes with living in a big city. Not having closure is the only closure I got. I realized how much we have taken safety and security for granted in Singapore. None of my friends have security alarm systems installed in their homes. I would also choose to believe that you wouldnt be able to get away scot-free if you commit any crimes in Singapore, no matter how petty your misdeeds are. You will be caught, in a very short time, or eventually. It is reassuring to know that so much effort goes into advancing science and technology for homeland security to keep Singapore safe. This to me, is the freedom the world needs. Freedom to be safe. MilipolParis

caption: The inaugural HacX! - Hack for Public Safety - jointly organised by HTX and brings together students from pre-university, polytechnic and university levels to harness the power of science and technology to solve crimes, secure borders, and reshape lives. Spanning across 5 weeks, the challenge saw nearly 100 team applications. From this pool, 35 teams were selected to participate in the semi-finals, and 10 teams made it to the finals held on 3 November. From these 10 groups, three winning teams were then chosen by the live audience and judges, and the first-prize winners walked home with $10,000!The participants demonstrated enthusiasm, creativity and innovation as they researched, conceptualised, developed, and pitched their solutions to the panel of judges. Throughout the journey, mentoring was also provided by our HomeTeam Departments and partner, Microsoft.What a great industry partnership to nurture the next generation of STEM talents in Singapore!HTXsg HTScienceandTech OneHomeTeam MicrosoftSingappre Technology Science Engineering

Through Hatch, we focus on collaborations with start-ups and SMEs, to accelerate innovations with dual-use technologies for public safety and security.HTXsg HTScienceandTech Repost kshanmugam_ [Launch of Hatch]Launched Hatch, an innovation centre established by .Given the quick development of technology, HTX understands the need to work closely with startups and SMEs, many of which are at the forefront of the latest innovations.Through Hatch, HTX aims to accelerate and validate some early-stage innovations that leverage emerging technologies for homeland security.Hatch will run Open Innovation Challenges twice a year and invite start-ups from across all industries to take up these challenges. cleaned_caption: Thank you Minister for launching Hatch officially last week! As the Home Team's force multiplier, there's a need for HTX to always be at the forefront of science and technology. Through Hatch, we focus on collaborations with start-ups and SMEs to accelerate innovations with dual-use technologies for public safety and security. HTX aims to accelerate and validate some early-stage innovations that leverage emerging technologies for homeland security. Hatch will run Open Innovation Challenges twice a year and invite start-ups from across all industries to take up these challenges. The start-ups will get to work directly with HT officers and HTX scientists and engineers. Funds will be given to selected start-ups to validate their technologies. cleaned_caption: A picture is worth a thousand words, a video is worth even more - we can now share direct video streams from our mobile phones during emergency calls. This is made possible with the Emergency Video System (EVS) which was jointly launched last week by Singapore Police Force (SPF), Singapore Civil Defence Force (SCDF) and Home Team Science and Technology Agency (HTX). Various HTX divisions were involved to offer their expertise, including the Policing and Civil Defence Programme Management Centres (PMCs) and xCloud. caption: You may be familiar with recreational UAVs. But the Beyond Visual Line of Sight (BVLOS) technology that we leverage for our Home Teams deployment of UAVs in the near future takes it a step further.Leveraging BVLOS technology means our UAVs can be controlled and monitored remotely from within a Command Centre. This will project police presence and augment manned patrols as well as provide wider area surveillance capability.BVLOS UAVs can also be used as first responders to emergencies by providing a situational picture of incident sites, such as major fires or terrorist attacks. As the Home Team force multiplier, HTX continues to leverage technology to enhance Home Team operations to keep Singapore safe and secure.Learn more about the BVLOS technology via the link in bio HTXsg HTScienceandTech UAV Drone BVLOS

caption: With close to 20 years of experience in the field of digital forensics, Sim Lai Hua has witnessed how quickly technology has evolved and the impact it has had on crime solving. caption: Starting today, the Robotic Escort & Security System (RESS) will be on trial at the Tuas Checkpoint. Conceptualised by engineers from HTX's Robotics, Automation and Unmanned Systems Centre of Expertise (RAUS CoE), this robot escort uses video analytics and environment sensors to self-navigate and guide travellers requiring further assistance from the immigration counters to secondary office areas. "The RESS live trials will provide valuable insights on how the use of robots and automation can enhance 's operations, to enable a safer and more seamless immigration clearance experience," shared Ong Ka Hing, Deputy Director, RAUS CoE. The trial ends on 11 November 2022.Find out more via the link in bio HTXsg HTScienceandTech Robotics Automation OneHomeTeam

caption: Presented with the mission to address real-world challenges faced by the Home Team, students from came up with some innovative robotic solutions under the mentorship of our HTX engineers! Among these solutions were A.L.A.N., an autonomous parachute system for safe landing of malfunctioned drones, as well as SLEEK, a soft robot that can brave rubble and rough terrains during search-and-rescue missions.We believe in doing our part to nurture the young robotics and automation talent in Singapore. It is heartening to see young talents from different engineering disciplinary backgrounds come together to solve real world problems in line with HTXs mission, said Cheng Wee Kiang, Director, RAUS Centre of Expertise.Learn more about the exciting projects via the link in bio! caption: We are grateful to receive the Public Sector Transformation (PST) Exemplary Innovator Award alongside , , and .sg! This award for the multi-agency collaboration recognises the innovative work that went into developing OMNII, a transformative digital platform that allows SCDF and hospitals to work together in an integrated manner so as to enhance the delivery of emergency medical services. Future phases of OMNII may include biometric authentication to identify patients and cloud-based AI technology for more intelligent operations and clinical treatment. OMNII is a great testament of a multi-agency, cross-ministry project that embraces technology to bring about higher efficiency and better outcomes for both users and the people we serve, said Ling Kok Yong, Director, HTXs Civil Defence Programme Management Centre (CDPMC). Find out more about OMNII via the link in bio

caption: Feeling the heat lately? Imagine what our Home Team uniformed officers go through! The warm weather may increase our frontline officers risk of fatigue and even injury due to heat exhaustion. One of the areas our HTXs Human Factors & Simulation CoE explores is the use of human factor science to optimise the design of the suits, tactical gear and daily operational wear worn by officers so as to reduce that risk. caption: Over the past few days, our Xponents took some time to have a bit of fun and recharge at our HTX Carnival , organised by our very own Healthy Lifestyle Committee! Not only did we receive snacks and souvenirs after enjoying the nostalgic carnival games, we had the chance to bond with our co-workers outside of work. We also had the chance to learn about the passions of colleagues through interest groups like Tabletop Wargaming, which provided many with a hands-on and therapeutic experience of painting miniature models, while the Cycling Community of Interest spurred on some friendly competition with a stationary bike challenge. We hope everyone had a great time! Happy Friday and have a rejuvenating weekend! HTXsg

caption: Thank you MOS for visiting the Protective, Analytical and Assessment Facility (PAAF) at Pasir Panjang Scanning Station on New Years Day 2022! Working closely with , our CBRNE scientists at PAAF play a key role in securing Singapores borders. Aside from employing the latest technologies to detect and deter hazardous materials in cargo shipments from entering our shores, our scientists also conduct checks and tests as part of biosurveillance, to intercept and counter invisible threats such as viruses and pathogens! Learn more about CBRNE Centre of Expertise via the link in bio. Repost Visited ICA officers at Changi Airfreight Centre and Pasir Panjang Scanning Station on New Years Day. At Changi Airfreight Centre, the officers brought me around to view our clearance booths. Due to the pandemic, more consumers have turned to online shopping for necessities, leisure and even groceries. Air cargo checkpoints have experienced a significant increase in volume of low value e-commerce. In 2020, ICA cleared over 21 million low-value goods through the air cargo checkpoints, which is double from the 10.5 million cleared in 2019. ICA also works closely with CAAS, MOH, Singapore Customs, HSA, SATS and authorised freight forwarders on vaccine imports, clearance and transportation through the air cargo checkpoints. Given that the vaccines have to be stored in very low temperatures, ICA ensures that the clearance process does not undermine the efficacy or delay the vaccine importation. At Pasir Panjang Scanning Station, ICA officers demonstrated how anomalies are detected during cargo inspection. Thank you ICA, for keeping our borders safe and secure. Wishing everyone a joyous start to 2022. GuardiansOfOurBorders OneHomeTeam HTXsg HTScienceandTech

Essential equipment is visible in the background, including scanners designed for detecting hazardous materials in cargo. This scene highlights Singapore's commitment to securing its borders while adapting to the growing demands of air cargo, especially during the pandemic's acceleration of e-commerce. No other notable objects or individuals are present in the background.

caption: Fancy a view from a Police Coast Guard patrol boat? except this isnt an actual boat! caption: What captures both iris and facial biometrics simultaneously to authenticate the identity of travellers at our checkpoints? Being progressively rolled out at Singapore's immigration checkpoints, the Multi-modal Biometrics System (MMBS) makes use of iris scans to not only make clearance more efficient, but more secure as well. With fingerprints prone to fading due to ageing, scarring or dryness, this contactless border clearance system means iris scans will replace fingerprints as the primary biometric identifier! Learn more about the collaboration between HTX and via the link in bio! HTXsg HTScienceandTech Biometrics

caption: When it comes to preparing our Home Team frontline officers for dangerous and demanding missions, not only is their physical safety important, but equally so, is their mental ability to manage the cognitive load required. This is why the Human Factors & Simulation Centre of Expertise (HF&S CoE) is exploring the use of S&T for adaptive workspaces in operation centres and training.With the EEG (electroencephalogram) headbands real-time measurement and monitoring of human performance indicators, it is possible to actively anticipate and adjust the work environment, task assignment or training level to better match an officers dynamic condition and needs. Swipe to watch a short video!At HTXsg, we always strive to be at the forefront of technology so as to harness it for our frontline to eXcel in their operations. Learn more about HF&S CoE via the link in bio.ScienceandTech MentalHealth

The headband, which features a sleek white design, is positioned perfectly on the individual's forehead, conveying a high-tech approach to assessing mental concentration. The participant wears a light blue mask and a navy striped polo shirt, along with an identification sticker. In the background, a researcher observes the data displayed on a monitor, suggesting a collaborative environment focused on enhancing the mental capabilities of frontline officers. The setting emphasizes the integration of advanced technology for improved operational training within Singapore's Home Team agencies.
cleaned_caption: When it comes to preparing our Home Team frontline officers for dangerous and demanding missions, not only is their physical safety important, but equally so, is their mental ability to manage the cognitive load required. This is why the Human Factors & Simulation Centre of Expertise (HF&S CoE) is exploring the use of S&T for adaptive workspaces in operation centres and training. Dr Henry Lee, a renowned forensic scientist and founder of Henry C. Lee Institute of Forensic Science at the University of New Haven, conducted an exclusive Zoom webinar at our invitation. A close strategic partner of the Home Team, Dr Lee has previously assisted the Police with several high-profile investigations. The session was well attended, with a number gaining new perspectives. Thank you Dr Lee for sharing with us your valuable insights! Click the link in our bio to read more about the session!

caption: A number of us would have dabbled with Extended Reality technology through mobile games like Pokmon Go or social media apps like Snapchat. But, did you know that it can also play a part in enhancing crime-solving? If you've watched the recent Mothership video on HTXs Human Factors and Simulation Centre of Expertise work (swipe to watch an extract!), you would have noticed that Mixed Reality (MR) technology was used in Bloodstain Pattern Analysis (BPA) training. Think holographic bloodstains and computer-generated surroundings that provide a near real-life experience in training scenarios for our crime scene specialists! Find out more about this training system by clicking the link in our bio! HTXsg HTScienceandTech
generated_caption: We are inside the Extended Reality Lab at the Human Factors and Simulation Centre of Expertise, showcasing advanced technologies such as the "Virtualizer" and "Cyberith" motion systems. These setups facilitate immersive training for crime scene specialists, utilizing Mixed Reality (MR) technology for Bloodstain Pattern Analysis (BPA). Notably, the environment mimics real-life scenarios, incorporating holographic bloodstains and generated surroundings for effective learning experiences. The lab exemplifies Singapore's commitment to integrating innovative solutions in crime-solving training. No people can be seen in the image, which focuses on the equipment and lab environment.

caption: The HTXsg Policing Programme Management Centre (PPMC) worked closely with the to engineer and design the Police Beacon. Through the integration of various sensors, audio and live-video technologies, the Police Beacon will allow members of the public to be connected quickly and directly with the Police in times of need, and enable interim sense-making by the Police, allowing them to better provide assistance. Prototypes of the Police Beacon will be undergoing trial in December at the Punggol Waterway Park Connector and Sengkang Riverside Park Connector. Click the link in our bio to find out more about the key technological features of the Police Beacon. HTScienceandTech OneHomeTeam

He finds the process fun and intriguing as it always requires him to think out of the box. It is no wonder then that his eyes sparkle as he tells us all about his internship project!Since the Singapore Institute of Technology undergraduates return from his all-expenses-paid trip to the RSA Conference, has been busy exploring the domain of information security to keep abreast of advancements. caption: If youve seen our post (bit.ly/cicwinner2019 - link in bio) on the winner of CIC 2019, heres Zhen Hao () giving us an update and sharing with us his experience on attending the RSA Conference 2020 in San Francisco last weekOur future intern said he had an eye-opening and mind-blowing experience, gaining new perspectives on the current security challenges from the expert-led sessions and keynotes. He stated that it was like a step into the future with countless exhibitions and each of them showcasing cutting-edge technologies that are not on the market, and solutions that were previously thought impossible to create. Another highlight he mentioned was meeting some of the creators of RSA up-close at the conference!Zhen Hao was thrilled to broaden his horizons by attending the physical workshops and trying car hacking and radio frequency (RF) hacking. He successfully manipulated the electronic device in the car such as the speedometer, door locks, starting the car and even deploying the airbags. He thoroughly enjoyed the hands-on experience of compromising a system as such an attack was only theoretically taught in school.It appears that Zhen Haos all-expense-paid trip has been most rewarding for him. CIC 2020 is happening again on 13-14 July this year! For those interested to join, look out for more details of enrolment for participation in May 2020! Follow our Instagram for updates!cybersecuritychallengeRSAConferenceSingaporeInstituteofTechnology
generated_caption: In this image, a young man stands confidently beside a high-tech display at the RSA Conference 2020, held in Singapore. He is dressed in a smart-casual outfit, featuring a gray zip-up jacket and a conference badge hanging around his neck. The display behind him features a complex setup of wires and technology, likely related to cybersecurity innovations. Prominently positioned is a laptop, which appears to be connected to the gadgetry, indicating an interactive demonstration. The backdrop showcases the conference banner in vibrant colors, emphasizing the futuristic theme of the event. The floor features eye-catching patterned carpeting that adds to the modern aesthetic. No other people can be seen in this part of the event venue, focusing attention on the showcased technology and the attendee’s experience.
cleaned_caption:
If you've seen our post on the winner of CIC 2019, here's an update sharing the experience of attending the RSA Conference 2020 in San Francisco last week. Our future intern said he had an eye-opening and mind-blowing experience, gaining new perspectives on the current security challenges from the expert-led sessions and keynotes. He stated that it was like a step into the future with countless exhibitions, each showcasing cutting-edge technologies that are not on the market, and solutions that were previously thought impossible to create. Another highlight mentioned was meeting some of the creators of RSA up-close at the conference! 

He was thrilled to broaden his horizons by attending the physical workshops and trying car hacking and radio frequency (RF) hacking. He successfully manipulated electronic devices in the car such as the speedometer, door locks, starting the car, and even deploying the airbags. He thoroughly enjoyed the hands-on experience of compromising a system as such an attack was only theoretically taught in school. 

It appears that the all-expense-paid trip has been most rewarding. CIC 2020 is happening again on 13-14 July this year! For those interested to join, look out for more details of enrolment for participation in May 2020! Follow our Instagram for updates!

caption: If youve seen our post (bit.ly/cicwinner2019 - link in bio) on the winner of CIC 2019, heres Zhen Hao () giving us an update and sharing with us his experience on attending the RSA Conference 2020 in San Francisco last weekOur future intern said he had an eye-opening and mind-blowing experience, gaining new perspectives on the current security challenges from the expert-led sessions and keynotes. He stated that it was like a step into the future with countless exhibitions and each of them showcasing cutting-edge technologies that are not on the market, and solutions that were previously thought impossible to create. Another highlight he mentioned was meeting some of the creators of RSA up-close at the conference!Zhen Hao was thrilled to broaden his horizons by attending the physical workshops and trying car hacking and radio frequency (RF) hacking. He successfully manipulated the electronic device in the car such as the speedometer, door locks, starting the car and even deploying the airbags. He thoroughly enjoyed the hands-on experience of compromising a system as such an attack was only theoretically taught in school.It appears that Zhen Haos all-expense-paid trip has been most rewarding for him. CIC 2020 is happening again on 13-14 July this year! For those interested to join, look out for more details of enrolment for participation in May 2020! Follow our Instagram for updates!cybersecuritychallengeRSAConferenceSingaporeInstituteofTechnology

cleaned_caption: If you've seen our post on the winner of CIC 2019, here’s the winner giving us an update and sharing his experience on attending the RSA Conference 2020 in San Francisco last week. Our future intern said he had an eye-opening and mind-blowing experience, gaining new perspectives on the current security challenges from the expert-led sessions and keynotes. He stated that it was like a step into the future with countless exhibitions, each showcasing cutting-edge technologies that are not on the market, and solutions that were previously thought impossible to create. Another highlight he mentioned was meeting some of the creators of RSA up-close at the conference! The intern was thrilled to broaden his horizons by attending the physical workshops and trying car hacking and radio frequency (RF) hacking. He successfully manipulated electronic devices in the car such as the speedometer, door locks, starting the car, and even deploying the airbags. He thoroughly enjoyed the hands-on experience of compromising a system as such an attack was only theoretically taught in school. It appears that the all-expense-paid trip has been most rewarding for him. CIC 2020 is happening again on 13-14 July this year! For those interested to join, look out for more details of enrolment for participation in May 2020! Follow our Instagram for updates!

caption: When Zhen Hao () participated in the inaugural Cybersecurity Investigators' Challenge 2019, heneverimagined he'd emergeawinner and earn himselfcash prize anda paid trip to San Franciscoto attendthe RSA Conference 2020!Recalling his intriguing and fascinating experience duringthe competition, the undergraduate at the Singapore Institute of Technology () quipped thatahighlight for him was "experiencing various real-life scenarios like live information gathering of volatile data from a computer to collecting fingerprints from a suspected plastic cup".Zhen Hao also felt elated when he managed to successfully solder a simple circuit board in order to communicate with a router management interfacea unique experience that helped him take a step back and appreciate the most essential part of a computer - the electronics and system architecture".As he makes his way to the RSA Conferencewhich started on 24 Feb, heis looking forwardto "many cutting-edge security technologiesbeing revealed at the conference".Followour Instagramforthe nextupdateon RSA Conference from Zhen Hao!cybersecuritychallengeRSAConferenceSingaporeInstituteofTechnology(Photos: Singapore Cybersecurity Consortium, Zhen Hao)

cleaned_caption: When he participated in the inaugural Cybersecurity Investigators' Challenge 2019, he never imagined he'd emerge a winner and earn himself a cash prize and a paid trip to San Francisco to attend the RSA Conference 2020! Recalling his intriguing and fascinating experience during the competition, the undergraduate at the Singapore Institute of Technology quipped that a highlight for him was "experiencing various real-life scenarios like live information gathering of volatile data from a computer to collecting fingerprints from a suspected plastic cup." He also felt elated when he managed to successfully solder a simple circuit board in order to communicate with a router management interface—a unique experience that helped him take a step back and appreciate the most essential part of a computer—the electronics and system architecture. As he makes his way to the RSA Conference which started on 24 Feb, he is looking forward to "many cutting-edge security technologies being revealed at the conference." Follow our Instagram for the next update on RSA Conference! (Photos: Singapore Cybersecurity Consortium)
